pageContext.claim: “If you look at some of the Kurds, as you know, that was -- that's a natural enemy of -- of Turkey. It's -- you know, specifically, as I said. I mean, they have natural enemies. They've been fighting each other for -- somebody said, today -- hundreds of years. I mean, one historian said they've been fighting for hundreds of years.”
pageContext.analysis: The Turks and Kurds have lived side by side for thousands of years. The conflict between Turkish citizens and the stateless Kurds is more recent and nuanced. The New York Times reported, “Turkey has been in conflict with the Kurdistan Workers’ Party, known as the P.K.K., since it launched a violent separatist movement in the country in the early 1980s. Both Turkey and the United States consider the P.K.K. a terrorist organization.” Plus, the argument that there is a long-standing internal conflict has often been used by U.S. government officials when they are avoiding intervening in a potentially disastrous human rights crisis.
